aws::graph::propositions: # Helicopter Accident at Heliport
The Tactical Flight Officer (TFO) put on his gear at the helicopter.
The Tactical Flight Officer (TFO) climbed into the helicopter.
The Tactical Flight Officer (TFO) fastened his seatbelt in the helicopter.
A lieutenant came to the TFO's side of the helicopter.
The lieutenant asked if they wanted to respond due to the weather.
The TFO indicated that the traffic helicopter (N911FA) was still flying.
The TFO stated they would return to the heliport if the weather was bad once airborne.
The TFO heard a loud bang.
The TFO saw the lieutenant run toward a fire extinguisher.
The TFO had not been aware that another helicopter had landed.
The TFO looked up and saw the main rotor of the helicopter he was sitting in was gone.
The Director of Maintenance was the on duty mechanic on the day of the accident.
The Director of Maintenance's mission was to maintain the helicopters.
The Director of Maintenance's mission was to assist with helicopter movement.
The Director of Maintenance assisted with moving helicopter N96BM outside of the hangar to pad 1.
The Director of Maintenance had not realized that helicopter N96BM had been placed outside of the pad 1 landing box.
The Director of Maintenance realized helicopter N96BM was outside the pad 1 landing box after disconnecting the auxiliary power unit (APU).
The Director of Maintenance started back to the hangar after disconnecting the auxiliary power unit.
The duty mechanic stated that it should not have been an issue because the helicopter was getting ready to depart.
The duty mechanic had observed helicopter N911FA approaching the heliport.
The duty mechanic had been inside the hangar for about one minute when he heard a loud explosion.
The weather at Bob Hope Airport at 1628 indicated visibility of 3 statute miles.
Bob Hope Airport is located in Burbank, California.
Bob Hope Airport is 8 miles west of the accident site.
The weather at Bob Hope Airport at 1628 included light rain showers.
The wind at Bob Hope Airport at 1628 was from 180-degrees at 6 knots.

text:
The TFO recalled putting on his gear at the helicopter, climbing in and seat belting himself in. The lieutenant came to his side of the helicopter, and asked if they wanted to respond due to the weather. The TFO indicated that the traffic helicopter (N911FA) was still up; once they were airborne, if the weather was bad, they would come back to the heliport. The TFO stated he heard a loud bang and saw the lieutenant run toward a fire extinguisher. At the time, he had not been aware that another helicopter had landed. When he looked up he saw that the main rotor of the helicopter he was sitting in was gone.

The Director of Maintenance was the on duty mechanic on the day of the accident; his mission was to maintain the helicopters, and assist with helicopter movement. He recalled that he assisted with the movement of N96BM outside of the hangar to pad 1. He had not realized that N96BM had been placed outside of the pad 1 landing box until after he disconnected the auxiliary power unit (APU) and had started back to the hangar. The duty mechanic stated that, due to the fact that the helicopter was getting ready to depart, it should not have been an issue; he had observed N911FA on inbound to the heliport. He stated that he had been inside the hangar for about a minute when he heard a loud explosion.

## METEOROLOGICAL INFORMATION
Weather obtained at 1628 for the Bob Hope Airport (BUR), Burbank, California, 8 miles west of the accident site, indicated visibility as 3 statute miles, light rain showers, wind from 180-degrees at 6 knots.
